subject: Re: [junit] Suite() method.
msgSnippet: I guess the first one is better, but in your particular example it doesn t matter ... In generall, your test class can be executed by any TestRunner (e.g.
messageBody:
I guess the first one is better, but in your particular
example it doesn't matter ...

In generall, your test class can be executed by any TestRunner
(e.g. Ant's junit task uses it's own implementation of TestRunner
or some IDEs integrating JUnit may use their own) and the suite()
method is recognized by those runners, which gives you
chance to control content of test suite in your test class.

If runner doesn't find the suite() method, it will use default
suite by creating

new TestSuite(ClassTest.class)


Vita


nataliabello@... wrote:

> which is the advantage of override the suite() method in a TestCase
> class.
> I mean, what is better to do:
> This:
> public static junit.framework.Test suite()
> {
> TestSuite suite = new TestSuite(ClassTest.class);
> return suite;
> }
>
> public static void main(String[] args)
> {
> junit.textui.TestRunner.run(suite());
>
> }
>
> or that:
> public static void main(String[] args)
> {
> TestSuite suite = new TestSuite(ClassTest.class);
> junit.textui.TestRunner.run(suite);
>
> }
>
